Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of plant-soil interactions in woody shrub expansion in the White Mountains of California
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant and animal distributions are changing rapidly as a result of environmental and land use change. Because species respond to these changes in different ways, the composition of ecological communities is also changing. One important result is the movement or "encroachment" of woody species of shrubs and trees into grasslands around the world. Because woody plant species have very different characteristics than non-woody plants, their encroachment can have dramatic effects. For example, encroaching plants may affect microbial organisms living in the soil, such as bacteria and fungi. These soil organisms are very important for nutrient cycling and soil health because they break down decaying plant and animal material and fertilize the soil in ways that affect plant growth. Therefore, changes in the species of microbial organisms, or how they function, could in turn affect other plants in the area. This research studies how a woody species, a sagebrush shrub, that is moving uphill in the White Mountains of California, affects composition and function of soil microbial communities and the plant species they associate with. This work will be helpful in improving land management strategies in areas experiencing woody plant encroachment. It will enable training of graduate and undergraduate students and outreach to a museum and local conservation groups.


This project will build upon previous work demonstrating that in the White Mountains, sagebrush has been expanding its range into alpine grasslands over the last 50 years. The project will integrate field and greenhouse experiments, modern molecular and enzymatic tools for characterizing soil communities, and plant demographic modeling to: 1) assess effects of sagebrush on soil fungal community structure and extracellular enzyme production, and 2) determine how these belowground changes feed back to affect the performance of other native alpine plants. The primary hypothesis is that native range-expanding species may affect soil microbial communities in ways that have critical feedbacks on the fitness of the existing plant community, including altering nutrient cycling and the relative frequency of pathogens vs. mutualists. This research will result in a more complete understanding of the above- and belowground impacts of alpine shrub expansion. Results will provide valuable information on the long-term status of alpine plant species under future environmental and landscape change, and the underlying mechanisms that link soil microbial communities and plant performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project included scientific discovery, international research collaboration, undergraduate and graduate student training and professional development, and community outreach and education.

Our work investigated how changes in global climate and land use are impacting high elevation alpine ecosystems both in California and across the world. These areas are undergoing changes from altered temperature, snowpack, livestock grazing, and season length. Together these changes have influenced a shift in alpine plant communities from primarily grasses and small flowering plants to more shrub and tree cover at higher elevations. We studied the impact of these changes in plant composition on the alpine soil environment, including soil microbes such as bacteria and fungi, soil water and nutrient status, and soil processes such as decomposition. 

Through our research, we discovered that the increasing cover of woody plants is changing both the diversity and the function of soil microbes and that these changes can be dependent on climate as well as characteristics of the woody plants like leaf size and chemistry. These new discoveries will help to promote further research about the impacts of climate change on alpine ecosystems both above- and below-ground and provide important information to policy-makers and land managers working to conserve and protect alpine ecosystems.  

This project brought together collaborators from 10 different countries across 4 continents and included researchers from both Universities and Government agencies. It created a global network of ecologists studying global change impacts on alpine ecosystems. This network will continue to carry out research and generate new discoveries for years to come. 

The results of this study were presented to the scientific community at both national and international venues including the Ecological Society of America meeting in Portland, OR in August 2017 and a gues seminar at the Institute of Ecology in Veracruz, Mexico in March 2018. 

In addition to scientific understanding, this project provided training to several graduate and undergraduate students who were able to develop new skills and techniques. In particular students became familiar with DNA sequencing technology, measurements of plant and soil chemistry, sample processing, experimental design, dataset management, and writing scientific reports.  Undergraduates received mentorship and professional development including preparation for job interviews, cover letters, and resumes. Students worked together as part of a team as well as conducting independent research which provided important real life experience for their future career goals.

Finally, the outcomes of this project were shared with members of the local community through outreach and education efforts. These included hosting science events for children and families at a local museum and nature center, presentations at chapter meetings of the California Native Plant Society, field trips to our research sites in the white mountains and scientific communication through an infographic created by a UCR student. These efforts to promote scientific communication and interest outside of the academic community help to create societal awareness of and concern for global environmental issues and to promote career paths in science to underrepresented groups.
